@sxjscience One comment on using (axis==-1) as summing over all. 
- This can be a bit incompatible with numpy's behavior on allowing axis to be negative. Although this is a minor thing, we might want to think a bit on how it can be avoided for future compatiblity.
- One way we can do is to support a nullable type in int setting. So user can pass in axis=None, while it get parsed as a special integer setted through configuration.

@tqchen Yes, it works well with cuDNN(just test with cuDNN v5).  
essentially, this fix only add adj to calc the output shape of deconv, the output shape in deconv is corresponding to the input shape of conv, so either with or without cuDNN it will works.  when not use cuDNN, the im2col and col2im will pad zero if the pixel in output feature map has no valid value during calc, and when use cuDNN, it will consider this too i think(just like conv).

@tqchen I'm thinking to directly implement `sum` Op in C++ with full numpy compatibility (multiple axes + keepdims). The new sum op may take two parameters, axis (TShape) and keepdims (bool). For the axis param, I can set the default to `TShape()` similar to https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/matrix_op-inl.h#L22-L28. However, the new Op will support limited NDIM if the reducing axes are not contiguous.

@piiswrong: there is a design issue with this symbol. As the "layer_num" is a parameter, the number of weights in this symbol can grow unboundedly. 

One solution (used by cuDNN and other interfaces to it [like Torch](https://github.com/soumith/cudnn.torch)) is to use only a single weight vector (whose size depends on the recurrent type, etc). 

The other solution is to expose all the parameters (a single GRU layer has 6 different weights and 6 biases...), and like concat symbol, let each of these take a list symbols, one per layer. The advantage of this is that one can more easily initialize certain weights/biases (though one could write a Python function that takes a RNN symbol weight, and converts it to all the individual weights + biases if needed for initialization etc).

What do others think?
i get what you mean, this means enrich the control flow of the graph to include condition, which is another direction that can be in parallel of this topic

2. As you said, if using batched learning, the target shape should be (batch_size, 1, sentence_maxlen, num_embed).

``` python

        X                  = train,
        eval_data          = val,
        eval_metric        = ['rmse'],

```

I finish it
I complete it by modifying the source code of mxnet, it seems to be simple and elegant.
I figure out my mistake.

When you choose mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput as last layer, the train loss function is encoded in that layer. `eval_metric = ['rmse']` is just for the train and val result feedback for us to tune the hyperparameters
ok thank you

Instead of 

```
F = E * C
executor = F.bind(ctx=mx.cpu(), args={'A': a, 'B': b, 'D': d})
```

Use

```
F = mx.sym.Variable('C') * mx.sym.Variable('E')
executor = F.bind(ctx=mx.cpu(), args={'E': executor.outputs[0], 'C': executor.outputs[1]})
```

Decompose the graphs so you can forward each separately
sym.get_internels

What you can do is to break the graph into parts, and use the imperative API to generate the sequence. So you can directly unroll on the imperative API. Take LSTM decoder for example, what we can do is to build a LSTM cell and dynamically unroll it like in torch.

The module API can help doing this. For example https://github.com/tqchen/mxnet-gan uses two modules to form a generator model. One for generator, another for discriminator, and alternate between the two
